course.subject: ELEC
course.name: System Modeling, Analysis and Control
course.description: This course introduces basic concepts, tools and techniques for modeling, analysis, and control of dynamical systems. The course starts from the use of differential equations to model continuous time systems. Examples from a variety of Electronic and Computer Engineering disciplines will be given to illustrate the modeling process. Then, basic tools needed for analyzing the behavior of dynamical systems will be presented. Finally, techniques for controlling their behavior will be introduced. Throughout the course, laboratory experiments demonstrating the use of these analysis/design tools will be included.
course.prerequisites: (ELEC 2100 OR ELEC 2100H) AND [MATH 2350 OR (MATH 2111 AND MATH 2351)]
course.exclusions: CENG 3110, MECH 3610

reviews.author: xjy
reviews.title: great course
reviews.comment_content:
basic robot control introduction. like all semester before
Week 1
L1. introduction/examples/applications
L2. state space models & linearization
Week 2
L3. Laplace transform
L4. transfer functions & dynamic response
Week 3
L5. transient & steady-state responses; DC gain
& final value theorem
L6. simplifying block diagrams, simulation and
implementation
Week 4
L7. MISO/SIMO systems & modeling of closedloop
systems
Week 5
L8. modeling case studies: magnetic suspension system, inverted pendulum system
L9. time-domain specification/2nd order systems
Week 6
L10. dominant poles/zeros, effect of extra poles/zeros, concept of stability & Routh-Hurwitz Criterion
L11. Stability of closed-loop system (skip robust stability)
Week 7
L12: introduction to PID control and system type
L13: pole placement design
Week 8
L14: mid-term on Oct 28th!!
L15: controller design case studies: magnetic suspension system, inverted pendulum system
Week 9
L16: steady-state response, system type and
internal model principle
L17: undershoot/overshoot
Week 10
L18: time-domain signals, system norms and
their computations
L19: open-loop vs closed-loop control, Bode's
sensitivity concepts
Week 11
L20: introduction to root-locus design method (1)
L21: introduction to root-locus design method (2)
Week 12
L22: Time-domain method (1)
L23: Time-domain method (2)
Week 13
L24: general design guideline and case studies: Ball and Beam systems
L25: course review
reviews.comment_teaching:
prof SHI is very willing to share more than the class with us.
we cannot only learn the control , but also some study methods and some university experience.
reviews.comment_grading:
very good grading.
4*hw + midterm + final
all assignments and examinations are easy as long as you attend the class.
reviews.comment_workload:
not very heavy.
if you have learned 2100 before, it is easy to understand all the lecture notes.
you can get more proof and exercise in the textbook.

reviews.author: HingZone
reviews.title: Easy Course
reviews.comment_content:
No need to understand the physics chapter. You won't see any of that in the midterm or final.
The proof part is too difficult to understand but the computation part is kind of easy.
Matlab computation is a must and it helps your life a lot
reviews.comment_teaching:
Just boring and a lot of derive. If you are really enthusiastic in learning, go lecture! If not, skip every lecture like me and read it yourself.
No need to ask the TA. They don't know either and there is no tutorial session
Source for homework and exams is a must because they are kind of similar.
reviews.comment_grading:
There is no marking scheme for your lab and hw. I copied my frds hw exactly and I scored higher than my frds. They just marked your paper randomly.

HW: All above 95% (mean 90%)
Lab: All above mean
Midterm: Above mean half a sd ( Counts 15% only)
Final: No shown
Grade A
reviews.comment_workload:
Easy af
If u are in the later lab session, all the lab were completed when u arrived. Just clicked  enter.
HW: exactly like source

reviews.author: GUO,JR
reviews.title: GENERAL COTROL COURSE in EE method
reviews.comment_content:
The content follows Prof. Shi Ling's way and focuses on the system part. And the textbook in PDF version was given before the semester.

It is mentioned in the previous ELEC3200 review. Just follow that.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. YAN gave good lectures in class. She can explain your question very clear with clear writing and explanation.

And TA replies to your email and questions very soon on weekdays. You can contact them during the weekdays.

But the lecture notes will be released after the lecture is ended. So you cannot preview your lecture content before the lecture begins. Or even when you grab your phone for ~3 minutes. It is hard to follow the content mentioned.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 15% mean:~91/100 for all
Midterm 35% mean: ~85
Final 35% mean: ~70

Although that I and my friends get an overall ~ 96.5. The final letter grade results in an A.

IF YOU STRUGGLE FOR AN A+. PLEASE CONSIDERING Prof. SHI's TEACHING. HE GIVES A+ GENEROUSLY.

You cannot make a single mistake in this course. Or you will not get an A+ finally. (Much more like in MATH 1013/1014).

A single mistake can make a great difference in the final grading. Please be aware of that!!!
reviews.comment_workload:
Generally, it will consist of 4 homework. And the questions come from the textbook.

The lab is optional for the online semester. So, it is a 4 credits course without a lab session. It can be a relatively light workload compared to other ELEC 3000-level courses.

If you want to attend the lab sessions, it is around the end of the semester in week 9 and week 11. The lab is about how to stabilize the pendulum.

A suggestion: You can self-study this course, which is a way easier to get the knowledge you should have known in exams. If you cannot understand, please just go to TAs and Prof. to ask questions. It is a waste of time if you are in year 3 or year 4.
IT IS ONLY WORTH IT FOR SELF-STUDY!!!

reviews.author: elessar
reviews.title: Easy and fun. But not enough content for learning
reviews.comment_content: Maybe I am being too PICKY. Professor Shi basically omitted all the math. God Damn this is a control course. What are you supposed to learn without all the matrix and complicated math stuff? Just compare the lecture slides with those offered by the university from the states or China, and you will know that this course barely teaches anything.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Shi is really funny. Plus he is an excellent teacher. He aspires us to think, not only just simply telling us what is right. This is an especially rare trait among all the Engineering professors that HKUST has. He also teaches other stuff about life. Not only academics.
reviews.comment_grading: The two exams (midterm and final) are very easy. Half of the class achieves 90+ out of 100 full marks. So I guess for the majority of the students who read textbooks and review the lecture slides after course. It will be an easy A. I could guarantee.
reviews.comment_workload:
For homework, the workload is very light. 4 homework in total.
But the lab is a different story! Hell of a nightmare. A lot of difficult stuff. Well, it is not hard academically. But rather they expect you to finish the engineering stuff without guidance. This is the place that I most dread, especially considering I do not have a teammate in the lab.

Coursebook:

Major Reference:
K. Astrom and R. M. Murray, “Feedback systems: an introduction for scientists and engineers”
reviews.comment_teaching:
The concepts are straightforward in the beginning until you reach the root locus near the end of the course.

The professor explains the theories very clearly, but you can understand just as well by reading the textbook and searching for examples on the Internet.

Professor Shi is very easygoing. He doesn't care whether we use computers or not for exams. In the end, almost all of us brought our laptops to the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: The questions are not that difficult if you can understand the concepts in the textbook.

reviews.author: iamwildcat
reviews.comment_content:
This is a broad elective from the ELEC 3000 series (which you may have realised coz of all the prerequisites for this course).

This course involves a lot of calculations requiring skills from solving differential equation sets to Laplace Transform to calculating signal NORM. (it's nothing really, coz in the exam you are allowed to use MATLAB to solve pretty much everything.)

Majority of the course is on finding overall system transfer functions and relationships between system variables & coefficients. Optimization was taught mostly in the last part but is also involved in the 1st & 2nd labs so its advised to really read through the content and get to know what you are about to handle.

If your mathematics / logic skills are not that good, or you seldom attend classes,  DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I am sure Prof QIU is professionally qualified in teaching system control, I mean he wrote the course textbook himself, but I must stress that THE COURSE ORGANIZATION IS JUST ABYSMAL.

The lab schedule was not released right until after add-drop period so we couldn't properly plan our timetables. Of course when it was released, BOOM, all classes clashed.
The professors' argument was if they put up the lab schedule early, students would be reluctant to join the course coz of the 3 hour lab period. I mean WTF, students will not join a course depending on how long the lab is , we've been through 2200 and 2400 we are accustomed to 3 hr lab sessions. Get to grip man.
OH, AND BEST OF ALL, ALTHOUGH WE HAVE LAB SESSIONS, WE DONT HAVE TUTORIAL SESSIONS.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got nearly minimum in midterm,
mean in final,
nearly full marks in all lab reports,
medium scores in assignments.

Grade C, nuff said.
reviews.comment_workload:
I dunno why but this seems to be the only ELEC3000 series course that requires writing a full lab report, and does not have tutorial sessions.

Full lab reports requires explanations of laboratory results and result printouts (from PSpice & MATLAB), takes a long time to compose, total 4 reports required.

Assignments require writing matlab codes for pole placements and such. If you know the concept it is quite simple, however if youre not particularly good in MATLAB that's another story.

Overall, the concepts taught in this course requires time to digest.

reviews.author: Jonas
reviews.title: Low workload course
reviews.comment_teaching:
normal
not interesting
but the professor knew control very well
reviews.comment_grading:
mid term:
mean:55 sd:23
final:
no stat
total score:77%, got B+ ( you need to ask your score to TA by yourself)

You don't need to attend the lecture if you want to get a good grade. Most of the contents discussed in the lecture will not be tested. There are 99 students in the class.I estimated that there are 20-30 non local students(Most of them seated at first two row). The prof. gave around 30% A range to the class(I guess) so less local students got good result.

P.S. All of my friends got C range.

reviews.title: best course ever
reviews.comment_content:
if you know I'm being sarcastic

if this is an elective pls don't take

TEACHER IS SO BAD

reviews.author: xixixi
reviews.title: Recommanded ELEC elective course
reviews.comment_content:
Basic knowledge and tools in the control system. It covered state-space model / system modeling / Laplace transform / transfer function / system stability / pole placement / sensitivity / 2rd order system / root locus.

There are 2 lab sessions that are not compulsory and you may attend based on your interest.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof SHI is really nice and would take care of students' confusion and explain more detailedly. He would pay attention to the mathematical proof and make sure everyone understand. He is not only someone who taught you knowledge and theory in class but a mentor as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework(x4): 20%
Midterm: 30%
Final: 50%

Nice grading and not harsh, understand every concept and it is easy to get an A range.
reviews.comment_workload: Not heavy la. Split 4 homework during the whole semester and it's usually 2-3 weeks per homework. And if you go review frequently then preparing for examinations is not that hard.

reviews.author: ee
reviews.comment_content:
All content comes from textbook written by the professor.
Ch1: Overview
Ch2: Modeling and Simulation
Ch3: Stability and Stabilization
Ch4: Time-Domain Analysis
Laplace Transfrom
No attendance is required.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Because of covid, zoom is used for online teaching. The lectures are quite boring because this course does not involved interesting materials.
Not all the TA will reply email or inbox quickly.
reviews.comment_grading:
There is no midterm in this semester. The weight of midterm distributed to HW4,5,6.
No grading scheme is released. The final exam score is also not released.

HW(1-6): mean 61%
lab(3,4): mean 75%
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework will be assigned approximately once every two weeks and will be due by midnight of the day when the next homework is published. The homework involves some problems that need to be proved, which are quite hard.

Unlike past semesters, we couldn't go to the lab and finish the lab under the guidance of TAs or professor. Students may find it difficult at the beginning, However, you can ask TA for help.

The workload is low since there is no midterm and we have enough time to finish the homeworks and labs.

reviews.author: zzzzzzz
reviews.comment_content: Basic control theory, controller design and the optimal controller
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lectures are quite boring since the prof. just read out the contents on the slides.
Don't try to ask the TAs anything related to the lectures because they can't answer those questions you raised.
reviews.comment_grading:
6 HWs (15%)
4 Labs (20%)
Midterm (15%)
Final (50%)

HWs: mean~80%                     Me:avg 95%
Labs: mean~86%                    Me:avg 99%
Midterm: mean:71.5/100         Me:100/100
Final: mean:69/100                 Me:84/100
Overall: A+
However, there's no clear marking scheme for the lab report, so you don't know which part you have been deducted a few marks.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is huge for a 3000-level course.
For each lab, you need to do prelab and it has to be included in your lab report. Besides, the content of the labs covers the whole syllabus of the course, which means you need to have a full understanding of the course at the beginning. Moreover, you have to do full lab reports with vague guidelines.
For the midterm and final, both of them are open notes, so you don't need to recite anything.

reviews.author: Jacky159159
reviews.title: Good for EE knowledge but bad of teaching
reviews.comment_content:
Laplace transform
modeling
PID control
optimal controller

It is hard to understand if you are not good at physic.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Qiu is a good professor, however, he doesn't know how to teach. As he do a lots of proof in the class and doesn't explain it well, there are lots of questions when i having the lesson. Therefore, you can self-study as there is no different with attending the class.

Also, the TAs were horrible BAD. I sent few of the emails to ask about the concept and grading and they didnt reply it or just "Please refer to lecture XX"
Hey, if i can understand by myself, there is no reason to ask u right?

And when i wanna know about my score for my reference and don't request for any paper checking. They reply me
" If you wanna check the paper, please come at XX on Rm XX, however, the TAs will check your paper more carefully and there are both possible to improve or deduct your mark as we are already used the "loose" attitude to mark your paper at the first time"

OMG, it looks like awing me ... LoL
reviews.comment_grading:
50%    Final exam  
15%    Homework (6 times)
20%    Midterm
15%    Lab (4 times): Pre-lab + Attendance + Report

HW mean 80%
MT mean 60%
Lab mean 80%
Final no show

i got
60% of hW as i miss one of them
70% in MT above half S.D
60% Lab as i get in to hospital and miss one of them and they still count it even i prove the proof.
Final no show but i think around mean range.

Therefore, i guess i am in the mean range or slightly below mean as the MT score cover the HW and Lab.

Finally i got B-, therefore, mean should be B-/B.
No good but not bad grade
reviews.comment_workload:
6 HWs
4 Labs

if you get source, HW are easy
if you get souce, Lab are easy too

reviews.author: A.J.
reviews.comment_content: A basic intro to Control Theory. Topics covered were the root locus, PID Controllers, state space representation, as well as linearisation. Unfortunately, the course was very theoretical. I would like to actually have implemented a bit more of what we learned.
reviews.comment_teaching: The Lecturer was very good, the lab Was were not very motivated
reviews.comment_grading: Quite good grades. Nevertheless, this year nearly everyone appeared to the lectures and he was really satisfied with the course participants.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was medium. Sometimes Matlab could be a bit annoying, but in general the homeworks and labs were easy

reviews.author: Yanghui
reviews.comment_content: The course is all about control theory. The materials are actually quite useful in many applications. A must learn for ECE students.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture might be slightly sleep inducing. You need to do some self study in order to fully understand the course.
reviews.comment_grading: It is very easy to get A range as long as you treat your homework carefully. The midterm is easy but final is quite hard. The
reviews.comment_workload: Moderate workload. The lab report is fairly easy to write. There are 5 problem sets in total. Each may take 1 ~ 2 hours.

reviews.author: garbage
reviews.comment_content:
The main topics are:
1. System Modelling (Changing everything into a set of ODEs. )
2. Designing Controllers
3. Drawing Root Locus
4. Modern Control Theory (Not tested. )
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor SHI's teaching is very clear and easy to follow. The last two lectures are very helpful. You will remember something useful even if you forget the control theories years after taking this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% homework
30% midterm
50% final
0% optional lab

The exams are very easy, easier than homework. And the time given is more than sufficient. Just be careful and you can get full mark.
reviews.comment_workload: Since the labs are optional, the workload is little if you decide not to do the labs. There are four homework assignments. They are not hard, but can be time consuming.
